awd_titl_txt: High-speed and minimally photo-damaging STED microscopy using nanolaser arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a fast, affordable, and miniaturized microscopy system to image the fine ultrastructure of cells, with minimal photodamage or photobleaching of fluorescent probes.   Success of this proposal will significantly advance the field of microscopy, specifically super-resolution fluorescence imaging. The development of high-performance, fast, compact and affordable microscopes will impact medical diagnostics such as cancer and Alzheimer's disease. 


The principal investigator will develop the next generation of stimulated emission depletion (STED) microscopy for high-performance, fast, compact and affordable STED microscopes. The PI will integrate metallic nanolaser arrays into STED systems which will greatly improve imaging speed and reduce the size and cost of the equipment

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy can visualize subcellular structures with below 200 nm spatial resolution and it has revolutionized fundamental biology and biomedicine. STED microscopy is one of the super-resolution imaging techniques and has been widely used due to its easy-to-use. However, it has several drawbacks including slow imaging speed, high illumination intensity and high cost. The objective of the proposal is to study the prospect of developing the next generation STED microscopy that might be able to overcome some of its shortcomings by replacing bulky, expensive and noncontrollable laser system with a novel type of light sources based on nanolaser arrays.

There were some of our findings/outcomes:

  • We developed a metallic nanolaser emitting at 785 nm which is suitable for STED microscopy.
  • We found an optimal recipe for the fabrication of the nanolaser.
  • We developed multiline excitation and detection imaging system which significantly reduces photobleaching and photodamage of the biological samples.
  • We developed deep learning network for denoising STED images, which substantially improve signal-to-noise ratio of images.

We expect that our new STED imaging system will allow ones to carry out fast and gentle 3D super-resolution imaging in living cells. However, we also found that there are still technical challenges in fabricating nanolaser lasers, which is possibly overcome by further optimization and development of recipes.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2022
Modified by: Kyu Young Han
